title: Discovering Precursors to Aviation Safety Incidents: from Massive Data to Actionable Information
segmentation: Welcome to the afternoon session.
I hope that you find this talk interesting.
I will admit that it's a little bit different than many of the talks that you'll hear at this conference, so I hope you find it interesting.

I have put together a few slides that talk about an area of research that we're performing at NASA that really touches a large swath of the public not only within the United States, but around the world.
Essentially, we're doing research on how to apply data mining as well as other technologies.
To the area of aviation safety and the aviation domain that we're talking about, it's really commercial aircraft, so the carriers that you fly a day in and day out.
I know many of you almost live on those airplanes.
Those are the carriers that we're talking about.
Those are the airplanes that we're talking about.
We're talking about looking at real problems that are emerging in the.
National airspace for arguments sake.
So problems that people might know about.
Maybe one person knows about it.

Maybe a few people know about and developing technologies to look at those, identify those automatically and then bring them in a decision support system so that people who are analysts can look at it and understand whether or not this is a real issue where there it's an emerging issue, whether it's something already known and so forth.
So we've got a lot of work behind this.
And frankly, Ness's spending a lot of money.
In this area, in order to make sure that this sort of technology can come to market and benefit a lot of people.
So.
This is excuse me.
So this is a day in the life of the national airspace, so each dot that you can't see.
So imagine that.

Seriously, imagine that this is a picture of the United States, and that there are little yellow dots, each dot swarming across the country in a cloud that is really remarkable, and you can see, and you can see these amazing of patterns that develop at different parts of the country so.
You tell me where they gonna develop.
They're going to develop in Chicago and Atlanta in New York in Washington DC, Los Angeles, and so forth.
Into these patterns come and they go, and as they come and go, what you see again and again is that these patterns are somewhat repeatable, but sometimes they're not repeatable.

Sometimes you see the same thing, sometimes you don't, and those of you that fly everyday know that sometimes you land at LAX where you land at Chicago O'Hare and everything works out smoothly and other times.
There is an aborted landing and you fly around and you get a good view of the Lake MI and you come back and then you try a second attempt and maybe even a third attempt along time ago.
This used to happen quite a bit, now it happens less often.
So the question is why does that happen Now if you ask air traffic controllers or if you ask pilots as we do a lot, they have theories.
They have specific reasons for these sorts of events to occur, but the question is, are there other kinds of events that we can mine and understand?
And at some point?
I will do a bit of datamining to figure out why that particular picture didn't come up, so hopefully this one does.
So in fact, I invite my friends at Microsoft to figure that out.
So this is a picture that shows the trend in aviation accidents as a function of time.

So on the X axis you can see time going back about 30 or 40 years, and on the Y axis is the number of fatalities and the key point of this picture is that the slide is showing that the trend is going down and down.
Here if you blow it up this is over the last.
Of 20 three years or so, you can see that the number of fatalities.
Is very very small as a function of time.
Now the question is, looks like the problem is solved, right?
If the number of fatalities is small and if it persists like that.
Essentially it could be a solved problem, but it turns out that's not the case, and the reason it's not the case is because a few things are happening at least a few things are happening.
Number one, the amount of air traffic is projected to grow very fast in the next 10 to 20 years, so we're looking at increasing air traffic.
Depending on how the economy expands, maybe by a factor of 3% to 5% per year.
So if you do the math, you can see that there's a doubling effect that's occurring.

A second issue that's occurring is that we're starting to introduce new types of aircraft into the national airspace, and this is going to cause some challenges, and this is going to cause some differences.
So even if the accident rate fatality rate stays pretty low, what's going to happen as traffic goes up?
If you multiply those two numbers?
The number of fatal incidents is going to rise, so there's a tremendous need for figuring out how to prevent those sorts of accidents from happening before they actually do.

So the approach that we take to this and this is a higher level approach than just talking about data mining, but frankly it it does draw a lot on data mining is first we have to identify what the problems are and this is an automatic identification.

So what this means is that we're going through massive amounts of data coming from aircraft coming from radar tracks, maybe even coming from the speech communication between the pilots and the air traffic control, going through data that are written reports.
About the aviation safety incidents that are occurring and so forth and identifying key precursors and then we evaluate those and we say based on expert opinion are some of these issues real?
Or are some of these issues emerging?
Or some of these issues, essentially false positives, things that aren't going to happen because those crop up and then finally we want to formulate a strategy and implement them.
Now I'd like to point out that NASA does not do the implementation of these sorts of decisions.
the FAA does that, but we work.
In close.
Aberration with them.
So this is really a global phenomenon.
Some have said that the the air space is the largest and most complex global.
Dynamical system that humans have ever created and this is a simple representation of it.
We have data streaming in from a variety of places from the air traffic control.
We have data coming from the aircraft as well as from a number of different agencies worldwide, and we'd like to develop a consistent framework for mining and understanding the data coming from.
Systems now, another important point is the data can arise from many different scales and the picture here on the on the bottom axis shows some notion of scale.
Think of it like 10 to the power minus six, maybe meters or or some measure like that all the way up to 10 to the six.
So this is a lot of orders of magnitude on the axis and we have data frankly, at the molecular level about how the composite structures are the aluminum structures on the aircraft or bending.
Put those bending modes.

Look like we have data about the materials sensor data, so this is where a lot of the sensor mining applications come in, where you're harvesting information directly from the sensors and trying to mind that from the software systems on the aircraft.
Half the cost of an aircraft generally goes into software, so this is an important area and then the engine's and the other subsystems of an aircraft that you think of.
So data is streaming from many of these areas, not necessarily from all of them.
We don't have streaming data at the molecular.
Level yet, but if some of our colleagues at Stanford get their way, we'll be actually very close to getting that level of data.
High Fidelity streaming constantly from every aircraft flying so.
The question is, you've been given a lot of data.
We have access to this data.
How do you actually look for an anomaly?
And I'll tie this back to the talk that we heard this morning in the same session where we had a different situation.
Instead of aviation, we had a medical situation.
Medical domain being discussed and they were talking about something very similar.
How do you look for precursors to a problem that's coming up?
So this is a chart that was developed by a colleague of mine at NASA.
In which he's showing how you can think of an aviation safety incident as a set of different states.
So on the X axis.

Here we've got state K -- 1 KK plus one all the way out to here, and the idea is that the system at large the system in question is going from one state to another, and it goes from a safe state to a compromised state to an anomalous state, and then finally into one of two or three situations that could end up.

In an accident itself, which is really bad, it could end up in an aviation safety incident, which is not necessarily a fatality, but it could be a situation where there was a near miss or some sort of problem like that, or it could end up in fact in some other sort of configuration.
So this is an important way that we think about it now, when we.
Tie this to real data.
What we find is that we've got accident data, operational data surveys.
You can take surveys of pilots and that has been done before.
Anecdotal reports as well as projections, and you can use this in order to D couple the information in that previous slide to figure out.
First of all what happened and the most objective way that we feel to figure out what happened is to actually look at the data itself.
So you look and you see on the telemetry what happened in this particular aircraft.
How did it behave?
What was different about it compared to the other hundreds of thousands of landings that occur at O'Hare?
What are some of the key differences?
So that's what happened and the type of data.
There is discrete and continuous.
Here the question is why did it happen?
Now it's difficult to look into telemetry data and figure out why something happened, because that's really a function of the pilots.
The air traffic controllers, and a number of other people that are involved.
So this is a different kind of question why something happened.
We believe can come from text data written by pilots.
When they say I was coming in for landing at LAXI saw a plane on the runway.
I took this particular maneuver in order to avoid an accident and the reason this occurred is because I was fatigued and there was a lot going on in the cockpit and there was also a bad weather.
And, you know, I had a fight with my spouse the other night.
And by the way, that does show up in some of these.

In some of these reports, so there's a whole host of reasons for things to figure out why something happened, and then finally the Holy Grail here predicting what will happen and what this requires, at least in my opinion.
And I think in the opinion of a lot of people that work in this area is a holistic view of data.
So not just partitioning the continuous and run algorithm A on the continuous beyond the discrete see on the text data and then hope for the best.
That's not the approach that we're trying to take.
We're trying to develop a holistic.
View of the information.
So here is an example aviation safety report.
You all can type in Asrs into your favorite search engine, download it, and look at it yourself.
It's all available on the Internet.
In fact, much of the text reports of this type is available on the Internet.
Just take a quick read here.
The pilot is saying just prior to touchdown at LAX to Tower, told us to go around because of the aircraft in front of us.
Both the copilot now, however, misunderstood the tower to say.
Cleared to land, etc.
So here's a pilot telling us about an aviation safety incident.
This could have turned out pretty bad if he or she hadn't taken the right.
The right steps.
Now clearly this can help answer the question, why did this particular incident occur?
It has about 100,000 reports.
Their multi multiple authors clearly, and there's also a very inconsistent use of abbreviations and punctuation, and so that makes it kind of a challenging.
Text mining problem.
I think you would agree now.
If we think about it, though, I didn't just talk about text.

I talk about delimiter data as well, so I put to get this put together this picture and I hope that it's clear here that on the upper left hand corner of the chart we have data that's coming from discrete and continuous sources, and the primary source here is an aircraft and it can help answer what happened.
As I mentioned before, here we have some text data and this can help answer why something happened.
And then down at the bottom we have network data and this network data is pretty different than the other types of data.
This is really about planes flying from London to Paris to Rome to Geneva and then maybe over to the United States and then back.

And if you think about it, that's kind of a network effect, and it turns out that those sorts of network effects are important in understanding aviation, so we'd like to have a way of combining all of this information in a seamless fashion.
I have given a hint there.
We've got K of XI XJ where?
K is a kernel function XI and XJ or two kinds of data, and we'd like to measure the similarity between those in the in the flavor of Mercer kernels and so later on.
And today we're going to have a talk which goes into this particular approach.
It's going to happen in the nearby conference room at 5:00 o'clock.
Not going to go into it in detail, but what I'll tell you is that the algorithm is designed so that it can take those four types of data.
In fact, any type of data where you can measure the similarity between two objects, for example, two networks, or for example two text reports or a pair of discrete and continuous measurements.
Whenever you can measure that.
This algorithm is such that you can kind of turn a crank and you will get a set of anomalies out and what's unique about these anomalies is they can tell you what happened.
In particularly why did they occur and so.
That's going to be discussed later.

But the question is, we still need to make predictions and those predictions are such that they need to be made on a variety of different types of data, for example, also on continuous data and they need to scale to very large datasets.
And what we've done here.
Is developed a Gaussian process regression method that can actually accommodate very large datasets, and I briefed.

At the last KDD conference they discussed this a little bit and today I'm showing you a little bit more information about it, particularly showing that with this algorithm that's documented in JML are from last year.

You can see that we're able to start making predictions on large datasets here all the way up to about 3 million points using Gaussian processes, and for those of you that work in the area, know that in fact most people talk about GPS in the realm of.
Maybe a few 100, maybe a few thousand points.
Certainly not in the realm of a few million points, so this is an innovation that we're trying to pull into this area so that we can make better predictions.
So one of the key questions that we have is how does human performance?
How do the human beings involved in the National Air transportation System affect safety?
Clearly, they play an extremely important role in that area, and I'm going to just talk to you a little bit about a partnership that we have with EasyJet.
It's like the.
One of the major carriers in the in Europe.
They do short haul flights and we're doing this very interesting and in my opinion at least a very ambitious experiment in which we're taking physiological measurements from the pilots as they fly.

Through bio harnesses were taking data from their airplanes were taking network data, were also taking reports that are linked by the way to the data that were given from the airplanes, and we're putting it all together at our lab in Mountain View in order to understand.
How does in specific human fatigue affect aviation safety?

And particularly, how does how do tired pilots and copilots react when they're under stress landing an airplane at a busy airport, and so this is one of the key areas that we're focusing on, and maybe in a year or two I'll be able to brief you on some of the results there.
We think it'll have some important consequ.
This is to the way regional carriers and others work.
So generally speaking, the data and the algorithm workflows as follows.
We've got a number of partners.
Southwest, Easy, Jet, HP and other global carriers.

They provide us with data or we provide them with algorithms, as the case may be, as that data comes through, we test it and study it using a variety of methods and the top box shows kind of Tier 1 algorithms.
These are algorithms that have been deployed by us that we understand that have gone through.
Pretty extensive verification and validation processes.
For example, IMS inductive monitoring system is used right now to monitor the health of the International Space Station as well as other major NASA assets.
So they go through the data goes through these algorithms and finally we provide results.
We can send them back to the carriers if they so choose, or it might be done at the carrier site and then we have Tier 2 algorithms.
These are the new ones that are under development that we report.
A conference is like this.
And what we're trying to do is move some of those algorithms from the bottom up to the top, so that we have a richer set of algorithms from.
To choose to do our analysis so the question is how do you get the word out?
So when we've got a partnership, it's pretty easy.
We just email the results, provide a report or something like that, but there's a much larger market than just those few carriers that I mentioned.
So we developed a system called Dash Link, which you all are more than welcome to sign up for.
Just type dash link into your favorite search engine, sign up and you can put your own code there.
Take our code, take the day to do with it what you want.
Post your results.
And so forth.
And we believe that this is one of the ways most important ways that we have to get the word out.
In fact, turns out that Southwest Airlines did just what they described.
They took the algorithms and downloaded them.
We sent some of our key players from our group to Southwest to help them install them and use it.

And it turns out that after running our algorithms, they found what they called operationally significant events, and that's a fancy way of saying that they found things in their data using our algorithms that were truly aviation safety incidents.
They incorporated these into their daily operations and.
And.
In fact, if you look at what they did, they did a small study using Orco, which we published here in 2003.
It was invented by Stephen Behan, Mark Schwabacher a couple of years ago.
It was used to analyze some data from Southwest Airlines and the analysis revealed, not surprisingly, data quality issues.
But then some more interesting things.
High roll and pitch events near the final approach fix, which is not necessarily a good thing.
And finally, hardnose over prior during prior to landing.

And so these are some of the sorts of events that you might have experienced personally on an aircraft that are now being tracked because of some of the work that many people at NASA have done, so I know.
They only have a few moments here left, and so I'm going to switch gears a little bit and just leave you with a different story.
Here I've talked to a lot about the applications that NASA has in the aeronautical area.
Indeed, the first A and NASA stands for Aeronautics.
That's what I talked about just now, but NASA has a lot of work going on the scientific domains and huge amounts of data.
You can.
I was joking with somebody the other day.
You can take those numbers, multiply it by 10.
You'll probably find somebody who says who claims they have that much data, so there's certainly a lot of data here.
One of the key areas that we're focusing on is in the Earth and space Sciences, and I'll tell you a little bit about that, by the way, that bottom item there, Kepler planetary discovery.
Just think about it, there are serving 100,000 solar systems every 30 minutes.
That is a huge amount of data just waiting for all of us to look at and to mine.
It's going to be made public, so.

So I'm going to tell you a little bit about the work we're doing in Earth Sciences, primarily to let you know of what I believe is an important application in an important area that you all might be interested in collaborating with us, and that's what we call the NASA Earth Exchange.
It's a collaborative earth science environment, and it.
Allows you to go through a website similar to Dash Link.

And this will be launched in August, by the way, and develop user communities and those user communities could be people who are data miners and earth scientists and others working together on a problem of large scale.
Do prototyping on the systems.

And then if those prototypes look like they're working out, you can escalate it and start using NASA supercomputers in order to do the studies and so down here we've got a supercomputing facility 8000 dedicated.
Cores.
Further, access up to 100,000 cores, which is I think a lot and over here a petabyte to 10 petabytes of information.
So this is coming out very shortly, and we would really look to you all in the data mining community as well as in the Earth science community too.
So to work with us and to help develop this, this is much bigger than me or my group or anything.
This is really about bringing together a few different fields.
The Earth Sciences, data mining and also pretty high performance computing.
So with that, I'd like to conclude by saying that I really want to thank the group members that we have at NASA.

Listed here as well as all of the funding sources that have made the sort of work that I described possible, so there's a lot going on in data mining, but our work is we're trying to branch it out and help as many people in as many different communities as possible, and what I really hope is that some of you developing new and novel algorithms would put them up on Dash link and let other people use them and look at them and start collaborations amongst yourselves with NASA and so forth.
This has happened already with some party.
Parties around the country and even international partners, and we're hoping that you all will do the same.
So with that, I'd like to thank you and I don't know if I have time for questions.

And if you think about it, that's kind of a network effect, and it turns out that those sorts of network effects are important in understanding aviation, so we'd like to have a way of combining all of this information in a seamless fashion.

In fact, any type of data where you can measure the similarity between two objects, for example, two networks, or for example two text reports or a pair of discrete and continuous measurements.
Whenever you can measure that.
This algorithm is such that you can kind of turn a crank and you will get a set of anomalies out and what's unique about these anomalies is they can tell you what happened.
In particularly why did they occur and so.

But the question is, we still need to make predictions and those predictions are such that they need to be made on a variety of different types of data, for example, also on continuous data and they need to scale to very large datasets.
And what we've done here.
Is developed a Gaussian process regression method that can actually accommodate very large datasets, and I briefed.

At the last KDD conference they discussed this a little bit and today I'm showing you a little bit more information about it, particularly showing that with this algorithm that's documented in JML are from last year.

You can see that we're able to start making predictions on large datasets here all the way up to about 3 million points using Gaussian processes, and for those of you that work in the area, know that in fact most people talk about GPS in the realm of.
Maybe a few 100, maybe a few thousand points.
Certainly not in the realm of a few million points, so this is an innovation that we're trying to pull into this area so that we can make better predictions.
So one of the key questions that we have is how does human performance?
How do the human beings involved in the National Air transportation System affect safety?
Clearly, they play an extremely important role in that area, and I'm going to just talk to you a little bit about a partnership that we have with EasyJet.
It's like the.
One of the major carriers in the in Europe.
They do short haul flights and we're doing this very interesting and in my opinion at least a very ambitious experiment in which we're taking physiological measurements from the pilots as they fly.

Through bio harnesses were taking data from their airplanes were taking network data, were also taking reports that are linked by the way to the data that were given from the airplanes, and we're putting it all together at our lab in Mountain View in order to understand.
How does in specific human fatigue affect aviation safety?

And particularly, how does how do tired pilots and copilots react when they're under stress landing an airplane at a busy airport, and so this is one of the key areas that we're focusing on, and maybe in a year or two I'll be able to brief you on some of the results there.
We think it'll have some important consequ.
This is to the way regional carriers and others work.
So generally speaking, the data and the algorithm workflows as follows.
We've got a number of partners.
Southwest, Easy, Jet, HP and other global carriers.

They provide us with data or we provide them with algorithms, as the case may be, as that data comes through, we test it and study it using a variety of methods and the top box shows kind of Tier 1 algorithms.
These are algorithms that have been deployed by us that we understand that have gone through.
Pretty extensive verification and validation processes.
For example, IMS inductive monitoring system is used right now to monitor the health of the International Space Station as well as other major NASA assets.
So they go through the data goes through these algorithms and finally we provide results.
We can send them back to the carriers if they so choose, or it might be done at the carrier site and then we have Tier 2 algorithms.
These are the new ones that are under development that we report.
A conference is like this.
And what we're trying to do is move some of those algorithms from the bottom up to the top, so that we have a richer set of algorithms from.
To choose to do our analysis so the question is how do you get the word out?
So when we've got a partnership, it's pretty easy.
We just email the results, provide a report or something like that, but there's a much larger market than just those few carriers that I mentioned.
So we developed a system called Dash Link, which you all are more than welcome to sign up for.
Just type dash link into your favorite search engine, sign up and you can put your own code there.
Take our code, take the day to do with it what you want.
Post your results.
And so forth.
And we believe that this is one of the ways most important ways that we have to get the word out.
In fact, turns out that Southwest Airlines did just what they described.
They took the algorithms and downloaded them.
We sent some of our key players from our group to Southwest to help them install them and use it.

And it turns out that after running our algorithms, they found what they called operationally significant events, and that's a fancy way of saying that they found things in their data using our algorithms that were truly aviation safety incidents.
They incorporated these into their daily operations and.
And.
In fact, if you look at what they did, they did a small study using Orco, which we published here in 2003.
It was invented by Stephen Behan, Mark Schwabacher a couple of years ago.
It was used to analyze some data from Southwest Airlines and the analysis revealed, not surprisingly, data quality issues.

High roll and pitch events near the final approach fix, which is not necessarily a good thing.
